title.text: Long-Distance Scrambling and Tree Adjoining Grammars*

introductionContent.text: Scrambling, both local and long-distance, has recently attracted considerable attention among linguists and computational linguists.
In this paper, we will explore the adequacy of the Tree Adjoining Grammar (TAG) formalism for dealing with long-distance scrambling I in German.
We will show that TAGs cannot capture the full range of constructions derived by scrambling.

I[owever, Multi-Component TAGs (MC-TAG), an extension of TAGs introduced earlier and utilized for linguistic purposes (e.g. for extraposition), can indeed capture the full range of constructions derived by scrambling.
We will also present an ID/LP variant of TAG to capture the same constructions, and then comment on the relationship between the two systems.
